intro: Mentha arvensis f. lanata, commonly known as woolly mint, is a perennial herbaceous plant characterized by its hairy, woolly leaves. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family and is native to temperate regions of Europe and Asia. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with square stems and opposite, ovate leaves covered in dense white or grayish pubescence. Its flowers are small, tubular, and usually pink or purple, appearing in whorls along the stem. Woolly mint is often found in moist meadows, woodland edges, and disturbed soils, and it has a strong, aromatic menthol scent.
